sections.section_title: Detect and Identify the DDoS Attack
tasks: Monitor traffic for unusual patterns (e.g., large volumes of traffic from a single source or IP range).
Use network monitoring tools to detect abnormal traffic spikes.
Check for user reports or service degradation symptoms.
Notify the incident response team immediately.
Ensure key stakeholders (e.g., management, affected departments) are aware of the ongoing attack.
Enable rate limiting on affected services to reduce the load.
Activate DDoS mitigation services (e.g., AWS Shield, Cloudflare).
Block traffic from malicious IPs using firewall rules or security groups.
Route traffic through a Content Delivery Network (CDN) to handle high volume.
Isolate critical services from the attack vector by diverting traffic.
Temporarily suspend non-essential services to preserve resources.
Inform affected clients of the DDoS attack and ongoing mitigation efforts.
Provide regular updates on the status of services and the expected recovery time.
Collect logs and traffic data for forensic analysis.
Identify the attack vector and patterns used in the DDoS attack.
Determine the source or nature of the botnet if possible.
Slowly lift DDoS protection and rate limiting once the attack subsides.
Ensure services are fully operational and no residual issues remain.
Conduct a post-incident review to assess the response and mitigation actions.
Document lessons learned and update the incident response playbook with any improvements.
Provide detailed reports to stakeholders and clients on the impact and resolution of the attack.
Strengthen perimeter security with more robust DDoS protection tools.
Ensure firewalls and intrusion detection systems are tuned to detect similar attacks in the future.
Train the incident response team on best practices for handling DDoS attacks.
